Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Small: Network-Level Design of Cyber-Physical Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cyber-physical systems (CPS) are engineered systems that are built from, and depend upon, the seamless integration of computational algorithms and physical components. CPS promise to revolutionize how we approach global societal-scale problems, through application of machine intelligence and autonomy in areas such as energy, healthcare, and transportation. A key element of the CPS promise depends on achieving effective networking of hitherto disconnected computer systems. However, the networked aspect of CPS also poses new design challenges. Machine-to-machine communication comes with inherent uncertainties, such as data losses, yet CPS have to perform under tight real-time, reliability, safety, efficiency and performance guarantees. When combined with rapidly growing increases in complexity, traditional approaches in which computation and communication aspects of such networked systems are designed separately, and in an ad-hoc manner, hinder achieving system-wide correctness guarantees and leave a large optimization potential untapped. The long-term goal of this project is to close this gap by investigating novel, systematic, and ultimately automated design approaches that enable network-wide optimization and validation of CPS across computation and communication boundaries. This is expected to advance how future intelligent and autonomous cyber-physical systems are designed, enabling whole new classes of smart applications to emerge.

The foundation for any rigorous design process is a sound formalization with well-defined abstractions and models that allow users or automated tools to reason about intended behavior before a system is built. While the integration of cyber and physical models has been studied, comparable theories for a unification of computation and communication are lacking. A key question is how application-specific notions of real-time behavior and quality-of-service can be provided for overall optimized implementations in the presence of inherent uncertainty, adaptivity and reactivity in networked and distributed CPS. This project aims to answer such questions by exploring formal foundations for a network-level computation and communication co-design science for cyber-physical systems. Specific innovations include: formal models of computation and communication for system specification, including associated analysis and synthesis algorithms; fast yet accurate performance models for rapid, early validation, including associated model generation, synthesis and design space exploration capabilities. These innovations are evaluated in the context of specific cyber-physical system case studies, including virtual and physical testbeds. Research is combined with an educational agenda aimed at establishing a holistic view of networking and embedded computing, including public release of models and tools as they are developed, as well as development of online teaching materials for a broad audience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Embedded and cyber-physical systems are promising to revolutionize how we approach many society-scale applications in areas such as transportation, health-care and energy. A large part of this promise is fundamentally based on enabling smart connectivity and machine-to-machine intelligence through networking of previously isolated systems. The networking aspect combined with the often very tight constraints of individual system devices introduce new uncertainties, challenges and opportunities for the design of such Networks-of-Systems (NoS). There are a vast number of design choices ranging from hardware resources in system devices over networking, middleware and runtime system configurations to choices of how to partition, map and distribute application tasks across devices in the edge network versus sending data to the cloud. Moreover, in many cases, such as the Internet-of-Things (IoT), systems are connected over open, public networks that are inherently unreliable and unpredictable. At the same time, it is often paramount that such NoS provide guarantees about their reliable, safe and correct operation while meeting stringent real-time, resource, performance or power constraints. Traditionally, the system devices, networks connecting them and applications running on top are designed and developed separately, and put together in an ad-hoc manner. This ignores inherent interdependencies and leaves fundamental design and correctness questions unexplored or unanswered.  

In this project, we have addressed such challenges by developing novel systematic and automated methods and tools for co-designing complex NoS architectures and developing the applications running on them. The primary result have been novel formalized approaches for NoS specification, modeling simulation and synthesis to explore associated design spaces and automatically derive optimized and guaranteed to be correct implementations. In particular, our work has led to the following specific contributions: (1) a novel NoS programming model that provides a deterministic and sound execution semantics while exposing necessary networking tradeoffs in an abstract and easily understandable manner to application programmers, (2) a compiler and runtime framework for automatically deriving optimized implementations with guaranteed correct execution schedules from NoS applications written in our programming model,  (3) a lightweight, general middleware for automatically and adaptively distributing application tasks across heterogeneous NoS clusters to optimize runtime performance while minimizing overheard in the presence of dynamically changing application scenarios, (4) a novel NoS simulator for fast yet accurate network/system co-simulation and virtual prototyping of NoS architectures and applications before they are built or deployed, and (5) a framework for rapid, and early design space exploration to support fully automated, joint network/system architecture definition, application mapping, and middleware and runtime system configuration on top of our NoS simulator.

Results of applying our NoS design flow to a range of NoS and IoT application case studies in both simulation and on physical testbeds have shown that it is possible to automatically generate NoS implementations from high-level, abstract application descriptions with real-time and correctness guarantees while maximizing their performance and minimizing resource or energy cost. We have specifically applied our approach to execution of deep learning inference applications on resource-constrained IoT edge clusters that would otherwise not be able to run such complex machine learning workloads directly. Using our exploration flow, we were able to derive new task partitioning,  mapping and execution strategies that enable running such applications in a distributed fashion with 68% reduced memory requirements and 2x improved speedup compared to existing approaches.

The project has also provided significant educational, outreach and technology transfer opportunities. It has supported one female masters student and two Ph.D. students towards their degrees, as well as research opportunities for several undergraduate students. Project results have been incorporated into undergraduate and graduate teaching materials, which have been publicly released. In addition, results have been presented at conferences, in several invited presentations and in two reference book chapters. Furthermore, on-going collaborations with other international researchers have been established. 

All combined, traditional and existing ad-hoc and isolated network and system design approaches ignore or over-simplify many complex interactions, thus are not able to provide guarantees and leave large optimization potentials untapped. Novel network/system co-design, modeling, simulation, synthesis and design space exploration tools as well as middleware and runtime systems as developed under this project promise to provide a major step in establishing a NoS design science, and thus developing the optimized, correct and safe NoS of the future. By transforming how such intelligent and autonomous NoS are designed, this work has the potential to enable whole new classes of emerging smart societal-scale applications to be developed. Towards these goals, we have released all tools and software developed under this project in open-source form.
